input_items.value: Destination: New York; Duration: 3 days next week; Hotel type: nice hotel; Restaurant preference: good restaurants; Budget: $3000. Number of travelers, exact dates, and currency type still need confirmation.

input_data.content:
You are the first contact agent collecting trip planning requirements.
    Gather the following information from the user:
    - Destination (where do they want to go?)
    - Start date and end date
    - Budget range
    - Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, etc.)
    - Number of people traveling

    Ask friendly questions to collect this information.
    Once you have all the details, use the update_context_tool to save them,
    then hand off to the destination research agent.
Quick business trip to New York for 3 days next week, need nice hotel and good restaurants, budget $3000

output_data.content:
Great — I can help. A few quick details to lock in the plan:

1) Exact dates: you said “3 days next week.” Which dates do you want (start and end)? If you prefer, tell me a preferred start day (e.g., Mon–Wed, Tue–Thu) and I’ll pick the exact dates next week.  
2) Number of people traveling (just you, or more?)  
3) Budget: you wrote $3000 — is that total for the whole trip or per person? Confirm currency = USD?  
4) Travel style: you said “business” and “nice hotel.” Do you want a business/luxury hotel (4–5 star) or something more mid-range? Any preferred neighborhoods (Midtown, Financial District, Upper East/West, SoHo)?  
5) Include flights/airport preferences or just hotel + restaurants? Any dietary restrictions or cuisine preferences for restaurants?

Once you confirm those, I’ll save the details and pass them to our destination research agent to find hotels and restaurant options.

Tell me those details and I’ll save them and pass the request to the destination research agent to find the best neighborhoods.

input_items.description: The user's initial trip planning request describing what they want

input_items.name: conversation_history
input_items.description: The full conversation between user and agent showing information gathering progress

input_items.name: required_information
input_items.description: List of required trip information: destination, start/end dates, budget, travel style, and number of travelers

input_items.name: collected_information
input_items.description: What trip information the agent successfully collected from the user during the session

feedback_config.ai_rubric:
You are evaluating whether a travel planning agent successfully collected all required trip information from the user.

Required information:
{required_information}

User's initial request:
{user_initial_request}

Full conversation:
{conversation_history}

Collected information:
{collected_information}

Evaluate session goal completeness:
- 'complete': Agent collected ALL required information (destination, dates, budget, travel style, number of travelers)
- 'partial': Agent collected SOME but not all required information (e.g., missing exact dates or travel style)
- 'incomplete': Agent collected very little information or session ended prematurely

IMPORTANT: Only evaluate sessions where the agent is actually trying to collect trip planning information. Skip sessions where:
- User is asking general questions (visa requirements, weather, etc.) without providing trip details
- Conversation is off-topic or not about trip planning
- Session appears to be testing/debugging rather than real trip planning

Provide your evaluation category and reasoning.
feedback_config.natural_language_disqualifier: Skip this session if the user never provided initial trip requirements or if the conversation is not about actual trip planning (e.g., general questions about destinations, visa requirements, or off-topic discussions).

You are the first contact agent collecting trip planning requirements.
    Gather the following information from the user:
    - Destination (where do they want to go?)
    - Start date and end date

    then hand off to the destination research agent.
Want to explore India's cultural sites for 12 days starting in February, interested in temples and local experiences, 2 people, $3500 budget

output_data.content:
Great — I can help plan this. A few quick questions to confirm details so I can save them and pass them to the research team:

1. Exact start date in February (day/month)? Are your dates flexible?
2. Should I treat the 12 days as calendar days starting that date (so end date = start date + 11 days)? OK?
3. Is the $3,500 budget total for both people or per person?
4. Travel style — pick one: budget, mid-range, or luxury? (You mentioned temples and local experiences — would you prefer homestays/local guides and slow travel, or a faster paced itinerary with more sites?)
5. Departure city/country (so I can estimate flights)?
6. Any mobility issues, dietary restrictions, or must-see / must-avoid places?

Once you confirm those, I’ll save the trip info and hand off to the destination research agent.

input_data.content:
You are the first contact agent collecting trip planning requirements.
    Gather the following information from the user:
    - Destination (where do they want to go?)
    - Start date and end date
    - Budget range
    - Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, etc.)
    - Number of people traveling

    Once you have all the details, use the update_context_tool to save them,
    then hand off to the destination research agent.
What specific regions or cities in India are you considering for exploring these cultural sites, or are you open to suggestions?

output_data.content:
Great — I can help with that. A few quick questions so I can narrow things down (please answer any you can):

1. Do you already have India as the destination? If yes, are there specific regions or cities you’re considering for cultural sites (examples: Delhi–Agra–Jaipur “Golden Triangle,” Varanasi, Kolkata, Rajasthan cities like Udaipur/Jodhpur/Jaipur, South India — Chennai/Madurai/Mahabalipuram, Kerala — Kochi/Alleppey, Hampi/Badami, Khajuraho, Amritsar)? Or are you open to suggestions?

2. Trip dates — what are your preferred start date and end date? Are your dates flexible?

3. Budget — what’s your budget range (per person or total)? Rough categories work too (e.g., budget <$1,000 pp, mid-range $1,000–$3,000 pp, luxury $3,000+ pp).

4. Travel style — what kind of trip do you want? (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, cultural/heritage-focused, family-friendly, slow travel, etc.)

5. Number of people traveling — and any ages (kids, seniors) or special requirements (accessibility, dietary restrictions)?

6. Any must-see sites or experiences (e.g., Taj Mahal at sunrise, Ganges boat ride in Varanasi, classical dance in Chennai, temple tours, festivals)?

7. Any other constraints or preferences (pace — packed vs. relaxed, preferred accommodation types, internal flights vs. trains, guided tours vs. independent)?

Once you provide these, I’ll save the details and pass them to the destination research agent to create suggestions and an itinerary.

What are the best times to visit each of these regions in February, and are there any local festivals or events happening during that time?

output_data.content:
I can help with that — first I just need a few details so I give accurate, useful answers for the regions you mean.

1) Which regions do you mean? (Please list each region or place — e.g., “Southeast Asia (Thailand, Vietnam)”, “Caribbean (Jamaica, Dominican Republic)”, “Southern Europe (Spain, Portugal)”, or specific cities/areas.)

2) Exact travel dates (start date and end date) in February — or are you flexible within the month? If flexible, tell me your preferred week(s).

3) Budget range — is this per person or total? Give a rough range (e.g., $1,000–$2,000 per person, or $3,000 total).

4) Travel style — pick one or more: luxury, mid-range, budget, adventure, relaxation/beach, cultural/food, family-friendly, romantic, active (hiking/wildlife), etc.

5) Number of people traveling (and any special needs: kids, seniors, accessibility, dietary restrictions).

Optional but helpful: Are you more interested in festivals/cultural events, weather/activities, or both? Any regions you definitely want or want to avoid?

Once you provide these, I’ll save the trip details and research the best times to visit each region in February plus local festivals/events.

Can you give me an overview of the climate in each region during February and what kind of clothing I should pack for the different areas?

output_data.content:
Happy to help — I can do that, but first I need a few quick details so I can give region-specific climate and packing advice that matches your trip.

1) When you say “each region,” do you mean regions of a specific country/destination (e.g., northern vs. southern Italy), or broad world regions (e.g., Southeast Asia, Europe, Caribbean)? If it’s a specific country, please name it and any regions/cities you plan to visit.

2) Destination(s) — where do you want to go? (city, region, or country)

3) Trip dates — start date and end date (please use YYYY-MM-DD or “Feb 1–12, 2026” style)

4) Budget range — total budget or per-person? (give currency, e.g., USD 1,500–2,500)

5) Travel style — e.g., luxury, budget/backpacker, adventure/active, relaxation/beach, family-friendly, mix, etc.

6) Number of people traveling

Optional but helpful:
- Any planned activities (hiking, skiing, beach, city sightseeing, festivals)?
- Are you packing carry-on only or checked luggage?
- Any clothing preferences or restrictions (e.g., want to pack light, need formal wear)?

Send those details and I’ll save them and then prepare a climate overview and tailored packing list for each region you’ll visit.

Can you give me an overview of the climate in each region during February and what kind of clothing I should pack for the different areas?

output_data.content:
Happy to help — I can do that, but first I need a few quick details so I can give region-specific climate and packing advice that matches your trip.

1) When you say “each region,” do you mean regions of a specific country/destination (e.g., northern vs. southern Italy), or broad world regions (e.g., Southeast Asia, Europe, Caribbean)? If it’s a specific country, please name it and any regions/cities you plan to visit.

2) Destination(s) — where do you want to go? (city, region, or country)

3) Trip dates — start date and end date (please use YYYY-MM-DD or “Feb 1–12, 2026” style)

4) Budget range — total budget or per-person? (give currency, e.g., USD 1,500–2,500)

5) Travel style — e.g., luxury, budget/backpacker, adventure/active, relaxation/beach, family-friendly, mix, etc.

6) Number of people traveling

Optional but helpful:
- Any planned activities (hiking, skiing, beach, city sightseeing, festivals)?
- Are you packing carry-on only or checked luggage?
- Any clothing preferences or restrictions (e.g., want to pack light, need formal wear)?

Send those details and I’ll save them and then prepare a climate overview and tailored packing list for each region you’ll visit.

    Gather the following information from the user:

Could you provide recommendations for specific activities or experiences in each region that align with the cultural sites I want to visit?

output_data.content:
I can — I just need a few details before I give tailored activity/experience recommendations for each region and cultural site. Could you tell me:

1. Destination (country/region or multiple regions you’re visiting)
2. Trip start date and end date (or approximate month/season if flexible)
3. Budget range (total or per person — and whether it’s strict or flexible)
4. Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, slow travel, family-friendly, etc.)
5. Number of people traveling (and any children or infants)
6. The cultural sites or regions you want recommendations for (list each region and the specific sites in it)
7. Any special interests or priorities (food, architecture, museums, living culture/markets, photography, workshops, performances)
8. Any constraints or needs (mobility/accessibility, dietary restrictions, pace preferences, must-see vs optional)

Optional but helpful:
- Are you already booked in particular cities (so we can plan nearby activities)?
- Do you prefer guided tours, private experiences, or self-guided options?
- Language preferences or local-knowledge priorities (e.g., want a local guide who speaks X)

Once you provide these, I’ll save the details and prepare specific activity suggestions for each region and hand off to the research agent to build a detailed plan.

feedback_config.ai_rubric:
You are evaluating whether a travel planning agent successfully collected all required trip information from the user.

Required information:
{required_information}

User's initial request:
{user_initial_request}

Full conversation:
{conversation_history}

Collected information:
{collected_information}

Evaluate session goal completeness:
- 'complete': Agent collected ALL required information (destination, dates, budget, travel style, number of travelers)
- 'partial': Agent collected SOME but not all required information (e.g., missing exact dates or travel style)
- 'incomplete': Agent collected very little information or session ended prematurely

IMPORTANT: Only evaluate sessions where the agent is actually trying to collect trip planning information. Skip sessions where:
- User is asking general questions (visa requirements, weather, etc.) without providing trip details
- Conversation is off-topic or not about trip planning
- Session appears to be testing/debugging rather than real trip planning

Provide your evaluation category and reasoning.
feedback_config.natural_language_disqualifier: Skip this session if the user never provided initial trip requirements or if the conversation is not about actual trip planning (e.g., general questions about destinations, visa requirements, or off-topic discussions).

input_data.content:
You are the first contact agent collecting trip planning requirements.
    Gather the following information from the user:
    - Destination (where do they want to go?)
    - Start date and end date
    - Budget range
    - Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, etc.)
    - Number of people traveling

    Ask friendly questions to collect this information.
    Once you have all the details, use the update_context_tool to save them,
    then hand off to the destination research agent.
Need a relaxing beach vacation in the Caribbean for 1 week in March, just want to unwind, 2 people, $4000 budget

output_data.content:
Great — I can help with that. I’ve noted: Caribbean, 1 week in March, relaxing, 2 people, $4,000. A few quick clarifying questions so I can save the details and start research:

1. Exact dates / flexibility
   - Do you have specific start and end dates in March (e.g., Mar 10–17)? Or are you flexible on which week in March?

2. Budget scope
   - Is the $4,000 total for both travelers and does it need to cover flights, accommodation, transfers, and activities? Or is that budget just for accommodation/land only?

3. Departure city / airport
   - What city or airport will you be flying from?

4. Island / resort preferences
   - Any islands you prefer or want to avoid (e.g., Bahamas, Jamaica, Turks & Caicos, Barbados, Dominican Republic, Aruba, St. Lucia)? Or open to suggestions?
   - Do you prefer all-inclusive resorts, adults-only, boutique hotels, private villas, or simple beach hotels?

5. Comfort level / amenities
   - What level of comfort are you looking for (budget, mid-range, upscale/luxury)?
   - Any must-have amenities (beachfront room, pool, spa, on-site dining, Wi‑Fi)?

6. Other considerations
   - Any dietary restrictions, mobility needs, or activities you definitely want or want to avoid (e.g., spa time only, snorkeling, nightlife)?

Answer whichever are easiest — the two most important for now are exact dates (or flexibility) and whether the $4,000 needs to include flights. Once you confirm, I’ll save the details and pass them to our destination research agent.

What are some recommended islands or resorts that fit my budget and relaxation criteria?

output_data.content:
I can help — to recommend islands and resorts that match your budget and relaxation preferences I just need a few details. Please answer the questions below:

1. Destination/region: do you have a specific place in mind (e.g., Maldives, Bali, Greek Islands, Hawaii, Caribbean, Seychelles, Canary Islands, Thailand) or are you open to suggestions worldwide?  
2. Travel dates: what are your start and end dates? If flexible, tell me date ranges or months.  
3. Budget: is this budget per person or total for the trip? Give a range (examples: under $1,000; $1,000–2,500; $2,500–5,000; $5,000+). Also say whether this should include flights.  
4. Travel style/details: you mentioned relaxation — do you prefer adults-only, all-inclusive resorts, spa-focused, private villas, quiet/beachfront, or something else?  
5. Number of people: how many travelers, and are there children (ages)?  

Optional but helpful: your departure city/airport and whether you prefer short flights vs. long-haul.

Once you give these, I’ll save the details and pull together island/resort recommendations.

    Gather the following information from the user:
    - Destination (where do they want to go?)
    - Start date and end date
    - Budget range
    - Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, etc.)
    - Number of people traveling

    Ask friendly questions to collect this information.
    Once you have all the details, use the update_context_tool to save them,
    then hand off to the destination research agent.
Need a relaxing beach vacation in the Caribbean for 1 week in March, just want to unwind, 2 people, $4000 budget

output_messages.content:
Great — I can help with that. I’ve noted: Caribbean, 1 week in March, relaxing, 2 people, $4,000. A few quick clarifying questions so I can save the details and start research:

1. Exact dates / flexibility
   - Do you have specific start and end dates in March (e.g., Mar 10–17)? Or are you flexible on which week in March?

2. Budget scope
   - Is the $4,000 total for both travelers and does it need to cover flights, accommodation, transfers, and activities? Or is that budget just for accommodation/land only?

3. Departure city / airport
   - What city or airport will you be flying from?

4. Island / resort preferences
   - Any islands you prefer or want to avoid (e.g., Bahamas, Jamaica, Turks & Caicos, Barbados, Dominican Republic, Aruba, St. Lucia)? Or open to suggestions?
   - Do you prefer all-inclusive resorts, adults-only, boutique hotels, private villas, or simple beach hotels?

5. Comfort level / amenities
   - What level of comfort are you looking for (budget, mid-range, upscale/luxury)?
   - Any must-have amenities (beachfront room, pool, spa, on-site dining, Wi‑Fi)?

6. Other considerations
   - Any dietary restrictions, mobility needs, or activities you definitely want or want to avoid (e.g., spa time only, snorkeling, nightlife)?

Answer whichever are easiest — the two most important for now are exact dates (or flexibility) and whether the $4,000 needs to include flights. Once you confirm, I’ll save the details and pass them to our destination research agent.

What are some recommended islands or resorts that fit my budget and relaxation criteria?

output_data.content:
I can help — to recommend islands and resorts that match your budget and relaxation preferences I just need a few details. Please answer the questions below:

1. Destination/region: do you have a specific place in mind (e.g., Maldives, Bali, Greek Islands, Hawaii, Caribbean, Seychelles, Canary Islands, Thailand) or are you open to suggestions worldwide?  
2. Travel dates: what are your start and end dates? If flexible, tell me date ranges or months.  
3. Budget: is this budget per person or total for the trip? Give a range (examples: under $1,000; $1,000–2,500; $2,500–5,000; $5,000+). Also say whether this should include flights.  
4. Travel style/details: you mentioned relaxation — do you prefer adults-only, all-inclusive resorts, spa-focused, private villas, quiet/beachfront, or something else?  
5. Number of people: how many travelers, and are there children (ages)?  

Optional but helpful: your departure city/airport and whether you prefer short flights vs. long-haul.

Once you give these, I’ll save the details and pull together island/resort recommendations.

feedback_config.ai_rubric:
You are evaluating whether a travel planning agent successfully collected all required trip information from the user.

Required information:
{required_information}

User's initial request:
{user_initial_request}

Full conversation:
{conversation_history}

Collected information:
{collected_information}

Evaluate session goal completeness:
- 'complete': Agent collected ALL required information (destination, dates, budget, travel style, number of travelers)
- 'partial': Agent collected SOME but not all required information (e.g., missing exact dates or travel style)
- 'incomplete': Agent collected very little information or session ended prematurely

IMPORTANT: Only evaluate sessions where the agent is actually trying to collect trip planning information. Skip sessions where:
- User is asking general questions (visa requirements, weather, etc.) without providing trip details
- Conversation is off-topic or not about trip planning
- Session appears to be testing/debugging rather than real trip planning

Provide your evaluation category and reasoning.
feedback_config.natural_language_disqualifier: Skip this session if the user never provided initial trip requirements or if the conversation is not about actual trip planning (e.g., general questions about destinations, visa requirements, or off-topic discussions).

Want to island hop in Croatia for 2 weeks, interested in Dubrovnik, Split, and Hvar, 2 people, $5500 budget

output_data.content:
Great — this sounds like a lovely trip. I have some of the info already but need a couple more details to save your trip preferences and pass them to the destination researcher.

What I have so far
- Destination: Croatia (Dubrovnik, Split, Hvar)
- Trip length: 2 weeks
- Number of people: 2
- Budget: $5,500

A few quick questions:
1. Exact dates (or date range / month)? — I need a trip start date and end date (or tell me if your dates are flexible).
2. Is the $5,500 budget in USD and does it need to cover international flights to/from Croatia, or is it for on-ground expenses only (accommodation, ferries, food, activities)?
3. Travel style — which of these best fits you: budget, mid-range/comfortable, luxury, adventure (active/outdoor), relaxation/beach-focused, nightlife/party, or a mix? Any priority?
4. Accommodation preference (optional but helpful): hotels, Airbnbs/apartments, guesthouses, hostels?
5. Any must-do activities or special needs (e.g., hiking, fine dining, beach time, nightlife, mobility constraints)?

Once you confirm those, I’ll save the details and hand off to the destination research agent to build an island-hopping plan.

What are the best ways to travel between the islands?

output_data.content:
Do you mean a specific island group (e.g., the Greek islands, Hawaiian islands, Maldives, Philippines, British Isles)? “Best” depends on which islands and your priorities, but I can help — first I need a few quick details about your trip:

Required details
- Which islands / destination are you talking about?
- Start date and end date (or rough timeframe)
- Budget range (per person or total)
- Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, fast/transfers-only, scenic, etc.)
- How many people are traveling?

Quick overview of common island-to-island options (depends on the destination)
- Scheduled ferries / car ferries: usually cheapest, can carry vehicles, good for short–medium distances; slower but scenic.
- High-speed catamarans / hydrofoils: faster than conventional ferries, slightly pricier, fewer crossings.
- Short-haul flights: fastest for long distances or remote islands; can be more expensive and subject to baggage limits.
- Water taxis / speedboats: flexible and fast for short hops or islands without ferry service; cost rises with distance and group size.
- Private charter boats or yachts: most flexible and private (good for groups or luxury), but significantly more expensive.
- Bridges/tunnels and combined road+ferry options: in some regions you can drive partway then ferry.

If you tell me the destination and the five details above, I’ll save your trip preferences and pass them to our destination research agent to find the best island-transfer options for your dates/budget. Which islands and dates are you planning?

What are the recommended ferry services or companies for traveling between Dubrovnik, Split, and Hvar?

output_data.content:
Happy to help — I can give tailored ferry recommendations, but first I need a few quick trip details so I can save them and pass them to our research agent.

Could you please tell me:
1. Confirm destinations and order — are you traveling between Dubrovnik, Split, and Hvar (and in what order or loop)?  
2. Start date and end date (or approximate/ flexible dates)?  
3. Budget range (total or per person — e.g., $200–$500 per person)?  
4. Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxed, fast/efficient, scenic, etc.)?  
5. Number of people traveling?  

Optional but helpful:
- Will you need to transport a car or just passengers?  
- Any mobility or luggage considerations?  
- Do you prefer faster catamarans or car ferries (slower but carry vehicles)?

Once you reply with those, I’ll save the details and move this to the destination research agent to get personalized ferry company recommendations.

What are the best ways to travel between the islands?

output_data.content:
Do you mean a specific island group (e.g., the Greek islands, Hawaiian islands, Maldives, Philippines, British Isles)? “Best” depends on which islands and your priorities, but I can help — first I need a few quick details about your trip:

Required details
- Which islands / destination are you talking about?
- Start date and end date (or rough timeframe)
- Budget range (per person or total)
- Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, fast/transfers-only, scenic, etc.)
- How many people are traveling?

Quick overview of common island-to-island options (depends on the destination)
- Scheduled ferries / car ferries: usually cheapest, can carry vehicles, good for short–medium distances; slower but scenic.
- High-speed catamarans / hydrofoils: faster than conventional ferries, slightly pricier, fewer crossings.
- Short-haul flights: fastest for long distances or remote islands; can be more expensive and subject to baggage limits.
- Water taxis / speedboats: flexible and fast for short hops or islands without ferry service; cost rises with distance and group size.
- Private charter boats or yachts: most flexible and private (good for groups or luxury), but significantly more expensive.
- Bridges/tunnels and combined road+ferry options: in some regions you can drive partway then ferry.

If you tell me the destination and the five details above, I’ll save your trip preferences and pass them to our destination research agent to find the best island-transfer options for your dates/budget. Which islands and dates are you planning?

feedback_config.ai_rubric:
You are evaluating whether a travel planning agent successfully collected all required trip information from the user.

Required information:
{required_information}

User's initial request:
{user_initial_request}

Full conversation:
{conversation_history}

Collected information:
{collected_information}

Evaluate session goal completeness:
- 'complete': Agent collected ALL required information (destination, dates, budget, travel style, number of travelers)
- 'partial': Agent collected SOME but not all required information (e.g., missing exact dates or travel style)
- 'incomplete': Agent collected very little information or session ended prematurely

IMPORTANT: Only evaluate sessions where the agent is actually trying to collect trip planning information. Skip sessions where:
- User is asking general questions (visa requirements, weather, etc.) without providing trip details
- Conversation is off-topic or not about trip planning
- Session appears to be testing/debugging rather than real trip planning

Provide your evaluation category and reasoning.
feedback_config.natural_language_disqualifier: Skip this session if the user never provided initial trip requirements or if the conversation is not about actual trip planning (e.g., general questions about destinations, visa requirements, or off-topic discussions).

I'm going backpacking through Southeast Asia for 3 weeks starting in January with only $2000 budget, solo traveler

output_data.content:
Awesome — that sounds like a great trip. I’ve got most of what I need but a few quick clarifying questions so I can save your preferences and pass them to the research agent:

1) Exact dates: do you have a specific start date in January (day/month)? I’ll use a 3-week length unless you want a different end date.  
2) Budget: you said $2000 — is that total (including international flights to/from your home) or just for in-region expenses? Also confirm currency (USD?).  
3) Destination detail: “Southeast Asia” is perfect as a region — any countries you definitely want to include or avoid (e.g., Thailand, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Myanmar)? Or are you fully open to a suggested route?  
4) Travel style: you said backpacking — do you prefer party/hostel scene, chill beaches, hiking/trekking, culture/temples, food-focused, or a mix? Any accommodation preference (dorm hostels vs private rooms)?  
5) Number of people: you mentioned solo — confirmed?  
6) Any other constraints or preferences I should record now: dietary restrictions, physical limits, visa/citizenship (for visa planning), must-do activities (scuba, trekking, cooking class), or pace (see a lot vs slow)?

Answer the ones you can and I’ll save everything and hand off to the destination research agent.

What about safety and health considerations? Are there any vaccinations I should get or travel insurance options you recommend for this trip?

output_data.content:
Short answer: it depends on where you’re going. I can give general safety/health guidance now, then I’ll need a few trip details (destination, dates, budget, travel style, number of people) plus any health concerns so I can save them and pass you to the research agent for destination-specific recommendations.

Quick health & vaccination checklist (general)
- Start early: see a travel clinic or your primary care doctor 4–8 weeks before departure (some vaccines require multiple doses).
- Routine vaccines: make sure tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis (Tdap), MMR, polio, and seasonal flu are up to date.
- Common travel vaccines often recommended by destination:
  - Hepatitis A (recommended for most low-/middle-income destinations)
  - Typhoid (food/water–borne risk)
  - Hepatitis B (for longer stays or medical/sexual exposure risk)
  - Yellow fever (required/strongly recommended in parts of Africa/Latin America; certificate may be required for entry)
  - Rabies (if you’ll be in remote areas, working with animals, or where post‑exposure care is limited)
  - Meningococcal (some regions, e.g., Hajj or certain African “meningitis belt” travel)
  - Japanese encephalitis (rural Asia travel, prolonged stays)
  - Tick-borne encephalitis (parts of Europe/Asia — if you're hiking in endemic areas)
- Malaria: not a vaccine — ask about mosquito prophylaxis (which drugs to take and when). Antimalarials depend on destination and resistance patterns.
- COVID-19: ensure booster per current guidance and check entry/testing requirements.
- Other precautions: insect bite prevention, food/water safety, avoid risky freshwater (schistosomiasis), altitude or heat sickness preparations as appropriate.

Travel insurance — what to look for
- Medical coverage: emergency medical expense limits and coverage for care abroad.
- Emergency medical evacuation (MedEvac): often the most important single feature — covers transport to appropriate medical facility/home.
- Trip cancellation & interruption: reimbursement for prepaid, nonrefundable trip costs.
- Baggage loss/delay and flight delay coverage.
- Coverage for adventure activities if you plan risky sports (e.g., scuba, climbing, skiing).
- Pre-existing conditions: check whether they’re excluded or can be covered with a waiver.
- Policy limits, exclusions, claim process, 24/7 assistance & hotline.
- Single-trip vs annual multi-trip: annual can be cheaper if you travel multiple times/year.

Recommended providers (examples to compare)
- Allianz Travel Insurance
- World Nomads (good for adventure travelers)
- IMG (e.g., Patriot)
- AXA Assistance
- Berkshire Hathaway Travel Protection
Also check whether your credit card already offers travel insurance/evacuation benefits.

Practical safety tips
- Register with your embassy/consulate for travel alerts.
- Carry paper/electronic copies of prescriptions, vaccination records (Yellow Fever certificate if applicable).
- Pack a travel first-aid kit and any prescription meds in original bottles.
- Avoid tap water where unsafe; be cautious with street food if at high risk.
- Know local emergency numbers; research local medical facilities ahead of time.
- Secure travel health/evacuation plan for remote or adventure trips.

Questions I need to collect (so I can save your trip context and pass to the destination research agent)
1) Destination (city/country)
2) Trip start date and end date (or approximate dates)
3) Budget range (total or per person)
4) Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, family, business, etc.)
5) Number of people traveling
Extra (health-specific):
6) Any chronic health conditions, allergies, pregnancy, or regular medications?
7) Do you already have travel insurance or a preferred provider? Any must-have coverage (e.g., MedEvac, adventure sports)?

Reply with those details and I’ll save them and then hand you off to the destination research agent who will give destination-specific vaccine requirements and tailored insurance recommendations. If you want, tell me the destination now and I can give immediate, specific vaccination and malaria advice even before you provide the rest.

- Allianz Travel Insurance

- Pack a travel first-aid kit and any prescription meds in original bottles.
- Avoid tap water where unsafe; be cautious with street food if at high risk.
- Know local emergency numbers; research local medical facilities ahead of time.
- Secure travel health/evacuation plan for remote or adventure trips.

5) Number of people traveling

What are some specific cultural practices or taboos I should be aware of to avoid offending locals during my trip?

output_data.content:
I can definitely help — to give specific, useful cultural tips I’ll need a few quick details about your trip. Could you tell me:

1. Destination (city or country)?  
2. Start date and end date (or approximate travel window)?  
3. Budget range (total or per person)?  
4. Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, cultural, family, etc.)?  
5. Number of people traveling?

Optional but helpful: any special concerns (religious sites you plan to visit, traveling with children, mobility needs, language ability)?

If you’d like immediate general guidance while you fill those in, here are quick universal tips that help avoid offending locals anywhere:
- Dress respectfully for the local culture (cover shoulders/knees in conservative places).  
- Remove shoes where it’s customary (homes, some temples/shops).  
- Ask permission before photographing people, especially in rural or religious contexts.  
- Avoid public displays of affection in conservative countries.  
- Use the appropriate hand for eating/gestures where relevant (e.g., right hand in parts of South Asia and the Middle East).  
- Don’t touch someone’s head (sacred in some Southeast Asian cultures) and avoid prolonged direct eye contact where it’s considered rude.  
- Observe local rules at religious sites (silence, no photos, head coverings).  
- Be cautious with political or historical topics—ask before discussing sensitive subjects.  
- Learn basic polite phrases (hello, thank you, please) — locals appreciate the effort.

Tell me the trip details above and I’ll save them and then give you tailored cultural do’s and don’ts for your destination.

What about safety and health considerations? Are there any vaccinations I should get or travel insurance options you recommend for this trip?

output_data.content:
Short answer: it depends on where you’re going. I can give general safety/health guidance now, then I’ll need a few trip details (destination, dates, budget, travel style, number of people) plus any health concerns so I can save them and pass you to the research agent for destination-specific recommendations.

Quick health & vaccination checklist (general)
- Start early: see a travel clinic or your primary care doctor 4–8 weeks before departure (some vaccines require multiple doses).
- Routine vaccines: make sure tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis (Tdap), MMR, polio, and seasonal flu are up to date.
- Common travel vaccines often recommended by destination:
  - Hepatitis A (recommended for most low-/middle-income destinations)
  - Typhoid (food/water–borne risk)
  - Hepatitis B (for longer stays or medical/sexual exposure risk)
  - Yellow fever (required/strongly recommended in parts of Africa/Latin America; certificate may be required for entry)
  - Rabies (if you’ll be in remote areas, working with animals, or where post‑exposure care is limited)
  - Meningococcal (some regions, e.g., Hajj or certain African “meningitis belt” travel)
  - Japanese encephalitis (rural Asia travel, prolonged stays)
  - Tick-borne encephalitis (parts of Europe/Asia — if you're hiking in endemic areas)
- Malaria: not a vaccine — ask about mosquito prophylaxis (which drugs to take and when). Antimalarials depend on destination and resistance patterns.
- COVID-19: ensure booster per current guidance and check entry/testing requirements.
- Other precautions: insect bite prevention, food/water safety, avoid risky freshwater (schistosomiasis), altitude or heat sickness preparations as appropriate.

Travel insurance — what to look for
- Medical coverage: emergency medical expense limits and coverage for care abroad.
- Emergency medical evacuation (MedEvac): often the most important single feature — covers transport to appropriate medical facility/home.
- Trip cancellation & interruption: reimbursement for prepaid, nonrefundable trip costs.
- Baggage loss/delay and flight delay coverage.
- Coverage for adventure activities if you plan risky sports (e.g., scuba, climbing, skiing).
- Pre-existing conditions: check whether they’re excluded or can be covered with a waiver.
- Policy limits, exclusions, claim process, 24/7 assistance & hotline.
- Single-trip vs annual multi-trip: annual can be cheaper if you travel multiple times/year.

Recommended providers (examples to compare)
- Allianz Travel Insurance
- World Nomads (good for adventure travelers)
- IMG (e.g., Patriot)
- AXA Assistance
- Berkshire Hathaway Travel Protection
Also check whether your credit card already offers travel insurance/evacuation benefits.

Practical safety tips
- Register with your embassy/consulate for travel alerts.
- Carry paper/electronic copies of prescriptions, vaccination records (Yellow Fever certificate if applicable).
- Pack a travel first-aid kit and any prescription meds in original bottles.
- Avoid tap water where unsafe; be cautious with street food if at high risk.
- Know local emergency numbers; research local medical facilities ahead of time.
- Secure travel health/evacuation plan for remote or adventure trips.

Questions I need to collect (so I can save your trip context and pass to the destination research agent)
1) Destination (city/country)
2) Trip start date and end date (or approximate dates)
3) Budget range (total or per person)
4) Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, family, business, etc.)
5) Number of people traveling
Extra (health-specific):
6) Any chronic health conditions, allergies, pregnancy, or regular medications?
7) Do you already have travel insurance or a preferred provider? Any must-have coverage (e.g., MedEvac, adventure sports)?

Reply with those details and I’ll save them and then hand you off to the destination research agent who will give destination-specific vaccine requirements and tailored insurance recommendations. If you want, tell me the destination now and I can give immediate, specific vaccination and malaria advice even before you provide the rest.

- Single-trip vs annual multi-trip: annual can be cheaper if you travel multiple times/year.

- AXA Assistance

Also check whether your credit card already offers travel insurance/evacuation benefits.

- Register with your embassy/consulate for travel alerts.
- Carry paper/electronic copies of prescriptions, vaccination records (Yellow Fever certificate if applicable).
- Pack a travel first-aid kit and any prescription meds in original bottles.
- Avoid tap water where unsafe; be cautious with street food if at high risk.
- Know local emergency numbers; research local medical facilities ahead of time.

What about safety and health considerations? Are there any vaccinations I should get or travel insurance options you recommend for this trip?

output_messages.content:
Short answer: it depends on where you’re going. I can give general safety/health guidance now, then I’ll need a few trip details (destination, dates, budget, travel style, number of people) plus any health concerns so I can save them and pass you to the research agent for destination-specific recommendations.

Quick health & vaccination checklist (general)
- Start early: see a travel clinic or your primary care doctor 4–8 weeks before departure (some vaccines require multiple doses).
- Routine vaccines: make sure tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis (Tdap), MMR, polio, and seasonal flu are up to date.
- Common travel vaccines often recommended by destination:
  - Hepatitis A (recommended for most low-/middle-income destinations)
  - Typhoid (food/water–borne risk)
  - Hepatitis B (for longer stays or medical/sexual exposure risk)
  - Yellow fever (required/strongly recommended in parts of Africa/Latin America; certificate may be required for entry)
  - Rabies (if you’ll be in remote areas, working with animals, or where post‑exposure care is limited)
  - Meningococcal (some regions, e.g., Hajj or certain African “meningitis belt” travel)
  - Japanese encephalitis (rural Asia travel, prolonged stays)
  - Tick-borne encephalitis (parts of Europe/Asia — if you're hiking in endemic areas)
- Malaria: not a vaccine — ask about mosquito prophylaxis (which drugs to take and when). Antimalarials depend on destination and resistance patterns.
- COVID-19: ensure booster per current guidance and check entry/testing requirements.
- Other precautions: insect bite prevention, food/water safety, avoid risky freshwater (schistosomiasis), altitude or heat sickness preparations as appropriate.

Travel insurance — what to look for
- Medical coverage: emergency medical expense limits and coverage for care abroad.
- Emergency medical evacuation (MedEvac): often the most important single feature — covers transport to appropriate medical facility/home.
- Trip cancellation & interruption: reimbursement for prepaid, nonrefundable trip costs.
- Baggage loss/delay and flight delay coverage.
- Coverage for adventure activities if you plan risky sports (e.g., scuba, climbing, skiing).
- Pre-existing conditions: check whether they’re excluded or can be covered with a waiver.
- Policy limits, exclusions, claim process, 24/7 assistance & hotline.
- Single-trip vs annual multi-trip: annual can be cheaper if you travel multiple times/year.

Recommended providers (examples to compare)
- Allianz Travel Insurance
- World Nomads (good for adventure travelers)
- IMG (e.g., Patriot)
- AXA Assistance
- Berkshire Hathaway Travel Protection
Also check whether your credit card already offers travel insurance/evacuation benefits.

- Register with your embassy/consulate for travel alerts.
- Carry paper/electronic copies of prescriptions, vaccination records (Yellow Fever certificate if applicable).
- Pack a travel first-aid kit and any prescription meds in original bottles.
- Avoid tap water where unsafe; be cautious with street food if at high risk.
- Know local emergency numbers; research local medical facilities ahead of time.
- Secure travel health/evacuation plan for remote or adventure trips.

What are some specific cultural practices or taboos I should be aware of to avoid offending locals during my trip?

output_data.content:
I can definitely help — to give specific, useful cultural tips I’ll need a few quick details about your trip. Could you tell me:

1. Destination (city or country)?  
2. Start date and end date (or approximate travel window)?  
3. Budget range (total or per person)?  
4. Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, cultural, family, etc.)?  
5. Number of people traveling?

Optional but helpful: any special concerns (religious sites you plan to visit, traveling with children, mobility needs, language ability)?

If you’d like immediate general guidance while you fill those in, here are quick universal tips that help avoid offending locals anywhere:
- Dress respectfully for the local culture (cover shoulders/knees in conservative places).  
- Remove shoes where it’s customary (homes, some temples/shops).  
- Ask permission before photographing people, especially in rural or religious contexts.  
- Avoid public displays of affection in conservative countries.  
- Use the appropriate hand for eating/gestures where relevant (e.g., right hand in parts of South Asia and the Middle East).  
- Don’t touch someone’s head (sacred in some Southeast Asian cultures) and avoid prolonged direct eye contact where it’s considered rude.  
- Observe local rules at religious sites (silence, no photos, head coverings).  
- Be cautious with political or historical topics—ask before discussing sensitive subjects.  
- Learn basic polite phrases (hello, thank you, please) — locals appreciate the effort.

Tell me the trip details above and I’ll save them and then give you tailored cultural do’s and don’ts for your destination.

feedback_config.ai_rubric:
You are evaluating whether a travel planning agent successfully collected all required trip information from the user.

Required information:
{required_information}

User's initial request:
{user_initial_request}

Full conversation:
{conversation_history}

Collected information:
{collected_information}

Evaluate session goal completeness:
- 'complete': Agent collected ALL required information (destination, dates, budget, travel style, number of travelers)
- 'partial': Agent collected SOME but not all required information (e.g., missing exact dates or travel style)
- 'incomplete': Agent collected very little information or session ended prematurely

IMPORTANT: Only evaluate sessions where the agent is actually trying to collect trip planning information. Skip sessions where:
- User is asking general questions (visa requirements, weather, etc.) without providing trip details
- Conversation is off-topic or not about trip planning
- Session appears to be testing/debugging rather than real trip planning

Provide your evaluation category and reasoning.
feedback_config.natural_language_disqualifier: Skip this session if the user never provided initial trip requirements or if the conversation is not about actual trip planning (e.g., general questions about destinations, visa requirements, or off-topic discussions).

Planning a road trip across the American Southwest for 2 weeks in April, 3 people, budget $4000, love national parks

output_data.content:
Great — that sounds like an awesome trip. I just need a few quick details to build the plan.

I’ve noted what you already said (two weeks in April, American Southwest, 3 people, $4,000, you love national parks). Please confirm or give the specifics below:

1) Destination — confirm “American Southwest” or any must-see parks/states to include (e.g., Grand Canyon, Zion, Bryce, Arches, Canyonlands, Monument Valley, Joshua Tree, Petrified Forest, Saguaro, etc.).

2) Start and end dates — exact dates (YYYY-MM-DD) or if you’re flexible, which two-week window in April works (early/mid/late April)?

3) Budget — is $4,000 the total budget for all 3 people, or per person? Is that flexible (+/-)?

4) Travel style — pick one or more: budget (camping, motels), mid-range (mix of campsites + budget hotels/Airbnbs), comfort/luxury (hotels, guided tours), adventure (lots of hiking/backcountry), relaxed (short hikes, scenic drives). Any preference for camping vs hotels?

5) Number of people — you said 3; confirm ages (adults/kids) and any mobility or accessibility needs.

Optional but helpful:
- Where will you start/end the road trip (home city or fly into/out of)?
- Will you bring your own vehicle or need a rental?
- Any “must-see” parks or activities (big hikes, scenic photography, stargazing, rafting, off-road)?
- Max daily driving you’re comfortable with (e.g., 3–5 hours/day)?

Reply with those details and I’ll save them and pass everything to the destination research agent to create an itinerary and recommendations.

feedback_config.ai_rubric:
You are evaluating whether a travel planning agent successfully collected all required trip information from the user.

Required information:
{required_information}

User's initial request:
{user_initial_request}

Full conversation:
{conversation_history}

Collected information:
{collected_information}

Evaluate session goal completeness:
- 'complete': Agent collected ALL required information (destination, dates, budget, travel style, number of travelers)
- 'partial': Agent collected SOME but not all required information (e.g., missing exact dates or travel style)
- 'incomplete': Agent collected very little information or session ended prematurely

IMPORTANT: Only evaluate sessions where the agent is actually trying to collect trip planning information. Skip sessions where:
- User is asking general questions (visa requirements, weather, etc.) without providing trip details
- Conversation is off-topic or not about trip planning
- Session appears to be testing/debugging rather than real trip planning

Provide your evaluation category and reasoning.
feedback_config.natural_language_disqualifier: Skip this session if the user never provided initial trip requirements or if the conversation is not about actual trip planning (e.g., general questions about destinations, visa requirements, or off-topic discussions).

Interested in a historical tour of Egypt including pyramids and ancient sites for 10 days, 2 people, $5000 budget in November

output_data.content:
Great — that sounds like a wonderful trip. I have most of the basics but need a few quick details before I save everything and pass you to the research team.

What I already have:
- Destination: Egypt
- Length: 10 days
- Travel month: November
- Travelers: 2 people
- Budget: $5,000 (need to confirm)
- Travel style: historical/cultural (your note about pyramids and ancient sites)

Quick questions:
1. Exact dates — what start date in November do you want (day/month)? If you’re flexible, give a date range or earliest/latest possible start date. I’ll use a 10-day span from that start date.
2. Is the $5,000 budget total for both travelers, or is that per person? Also, should that budget include international flights or just in-country costs (tours, hotels, internal flights)?
3. Accommodation level preference: budget, mid-range, or luxury?
4. Tour style: do you prefer a private guide/driver, small group tours, or self-guided with occasional guided excursions?
5. Any must-see sites you definitely want included (e.g., Giza pyramids & Sphinx, Saqqara, Egyptian Museum, Luxor — Karnak & Valley of the Kings, Aswan, Abu Simbel, Nile cruise)?
6. Departure city (or country) for estimating flights/practicalities?
7. Any mobility constraints, dietary needs, or other special requirements?

Answer the ones you can and I’ll save the trip details and hand you off to the destination research agent.

What about visa requirements for Egypt? Do we need to apply in advance, or can we get it on arrival?

output_data.content:
Yes — I can help. Quick summary first, then a couple of questions so I can give you the exact visa steps for your situation.

Quick, general guidance (as of mid‑2024):
- Many nationalities (including US, UK, EU, Canada, Australia, NZ) can get an Egypt e‑Visa online before travel or a visa on arrival at major airports for short tourist stays (commonly single‑entry ~30 days).  
- I recommend the e‑Visa in advance to avoid queues and any on‑arrival surprises.  
- Passport should generally be valid for at least 6 months from entry and have blank pages.  
- If you’re arriving from a country with yellow fever risk, a vaccination certificate may be required.  
- Some nationalities must obtain a visa from an Egyptian consulate before travel — so the exact rules depend on your passport.

To give you a definitive answer and step‑by‑step instructions (including fees, forms, and whether you need to apply in advance), I need a few details:

1) Confirm destination: Egypt (any specific city/entry airport like Cairo, Sharm el‑Sheikh, Hurghada)?  
2) What is your passport nationality (which country issued your passport)?  
3) Travel dates: start date and end date (or approximate month)?  
4) How many people are traveling?  
5) Budget range for the trip?  
6) Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, family, etc.)?

Give me those and I’ll (a) tell you exactly whether you can do e‑Visa or visa‑on‑arrival for your passport, (b) list required documents/fees, and (c) save your trip details and hand you off to the destination research agent if you want planning help.

What are the typical costs for accommodation and meals in Egypt, so we can better plan our budget?

output_data.content:
Great question — happy to help. Below are typical cost ranges for accommodation and meals in Egypt (rounded and in USD for easy planning). Costs vary by city (Cairo, Alexandria, Luxor/Aswan, Red Sea resorts like Hurghada/Sharm El-Sheikh) and by season, but these ranges give a practical starting point.

Accommodation (per night, per room)
- Budget hostels / guesthouses: $5–$25 (dorm beds $5–10; private budget rooms $15–25)
- Mid‑range hotels (2–3★ / small 4★): $30–$90
- Comfortable 4★ hotels: $90–$180
- Luxury / 5★ hotels and resorts (especially Red Sea): $180–400+
Notes: Many mid-range hotels include breakfast. Red Sea resorts and luxury hotels are on the higher end of the range.

Meals (per person)
- Street food / very cheap local eats (koshari, falafel, shawarma): $1–$4
- Casual local restaurant or café meal: $3–$8
- Mid‑range restaurant (sit‑down, one drink): $8–$20
- Fine dining / hotel restaurants: $25–$60+
Notes: Tipping of ~10% is customary if service charge isn’t included. Hotel restaurants and tourist areas tend to be pricier.

Daily budget examples (per person) — accommodation + meals only
- Budget traveler: $25–45/day (dorm or cheap private room + street/local meals)
- Comfortable/mid‑range: $60–120/day (basic private room or 3★ hotel + mixed casual/mid‑range meals)
- Luxury traveler: $200+/day (4–5★ hotels and nicer restaurants)

Other quick tips
- Red Sea resort towns (Hurghada, Sharm) and some Nile cruise-based stays are significantly pricier than Upper Egypt (Luxor/Aswan) or many spots in Cairo.
- Peak tourist season (roughly Oct–Apr) can push prices up; summer is hot but sometimes cheaper except beach resorts.
- Prices quoted in USD are common for tourist services; local currency (EGP) rates fluctuate — use up‑to‑date exchange rates when finalizing budgets.
- Activities (tours, entry fees, Nile cruises, diving) and internal transport are additional — I can estimate those once I know your plan.

A few quick questions so I can save your trip details and pass them to our destination research agent:
1) Destination — you mentioned Egypt; any specific cities/regions (Cairo, Luxor, Aswan, Red Sea resorts, Nile cruise)?
2) Start date and end date (or approximate travel window)?
3) Budget range for the whole trip (total or per person)?
4) Travel style (budget, mid‑range/comfortable, luxury, adventure, relaxation, family, etc.)?
5) How many people are traveling?
6) Any special needs or priorities (kids, accessibility, dietary restrictions, must‑see activities)?

Give me those details and I’ll save them and hand off to the destination research agent to draft a tailored plan.

What about visa requirements for Egypt? Do we need to apply in advance, or can we get it on arrival?

output_data.content:
Yes — I can help. Quick summary first, then a couple of questions so I can give you the exact visa steps for your situation.

Quick, general guidance (as of mid‑2024):
- Many nationalities (including US, UK, EU, Canada, Australia, NZ) can get an Egypt e‑Visa online before travel or a visa on arrival at major airports for short tourist stays (commonly single‑entry ~30 days).  
- I recommend the e‑Visa in advance to avoid queues and any on‑arrival surprises.  
- Passport should generally be valid for at least 6 months from entry and have blank pages.  
- If you’re arriving from a country with yellow fever risk, a vaccination certificate may be required.  
- Some nationalities must obtain a visa from an Egyptian consulate before travel — so the exact rules depend on your passport.

To give you a definitive answer and step‑by‑step instructions (including fees, forms, and whether you need to apply in advance), I need a few details:

1) Confirm destination: Egypt (any specific city/entry airport like Cairo, Sharm el‑Sheikh, Hurghada)?  
2) What is your passport nationality (which country issued your passport)?  
3) Travel dates: start date and end date (or approximate month)?  
4) How many people are traveling?  
5) Budget range for the trip?  
6) Travel style (luxury, budget, adventure, relaxation, family, etc.)?

Give me those and I’ll (a) tell you exactly whether you can do e‑Visa or visa‑on‑arrival for your passport, (b) list required documents/fees, and (c) save your trip details and hand you off to the destination research agent if you want planning help.

What are the typical costs for accommodation and meals in Egypt, so we can better plan our budget?

output_data.content:
Great question — happy to help. Below are typical cost ranges for accommodation and meals in Egypt (rounded and in USD for easy planning). Costs vary by city (Cairo, Alexandria, Luxor/Aswan, Red Sea resorts like Hurghada/Sharm El-Sheikh) and by season, but these ranges give a practical starting point.

Accommodation (per night, per room)
- Budget hostels / guesthouses: $5–$25 (dorm beds $5–10; private budget rooms $15–25)
- Mid‑range hotels (2–3★ / small 4★): $30–$90
- Comfortable 4★ hotels: $90–$180
- Luxury / 5★ hotels and resorts (especially Red Sea): $180–400+
Notes: Many mid-range hotels include breakfast. Red Sea resorts and luxury hotels are on the higher end of the range.

Meals (per person)
- Street food / very cheap local eats (koshari, falafel, shawarma): $1–$4
- Casual local restaurant or café meal: $3–$8
- Mid‑range restaurant (sit‑down, one drink): $8–$20
- Fine dining / hotel restaurants: $25–$60+
Notes: Tipping of ~10% is customary if service charge isn’t included. Hotel restaurants and tourist areas tend to be pricier.

Daily budget examples (per person) — accommodation + meals only
- Budget traveler: $25–45/day (dorm or cheap private room + street/local meals)
- Comfortable/mid‑range: $60–120/day (basic private room or 3★ hotel + mixed casual/mid‑range meals)
- Luxury traveler: $200+/day (4–5★ hotels and nicer restaurants)

Other quick tips
- Red Sea resort towns (Hurghada, Sharm) and some Nile cruise-based stays are significantly pricier than Upper Egypt (Luxor/Aswan) or many spots in Cairo.
- Peak tourist season (roughly Oct–Apr) can push prices up; summer is hot but sometimes cheaper except beach resorts.
- Prices quoted in USD are common for tourist services; local currency (EGP) rates fluctuate — use up‑to‑date exchange rates when finalizing budgets.
- Activities (tours, entry fees, Nile cruises, diving) and internal transport are additional — I can estimate those once I know your plan.

A few quick questions so I can save your trip details and pass them to our destination research agent:
1) Destination — you mentioned Egypt; any specific cities/regions (Cairo, Luxor, Aswan, Red Sea resorts, Nile cruise)?
2) Start date and end date (or approximate travel window)?
3) Budget range for the whole trip (total or per person)?
4) Travel style (budget, mid‑range/comfortable, luxury, adventure, relaxation, family, etc.)?
5) How many people are traveling?
6) Any special needs or priorities (kids, accessibility, dietary restrictions, must‑see activities)?

Give me those details and I’ll save them and hand off to the destination research agent to draft a tailored plan.

feedback_config.ai_rubric:
You are evaluating whether a travel planning agent successfully collected all required trip information from the user.

Required information:
{required_information}

User's initial request:
{user_initial_request}

Full conversation:
{conversation_history}

Collected information:
{collected_information}

Evaluate session goal completeness:
- 'complete': Agent collected ALL required information (destination, dates, budget, travel style, number of travelers)
- 'partial': Agent collected SOME but not all required information (e.g., missing exact dates or travel style)
- 'incomplete': Agent collected very little information or session ended prematurely

What are the best cities in Vietnam for culinary experiences, and should I focus on just a few places or travel around?

output_data.content:
Great question — Vietnam is one of the world’s best countries for food. Quick summary plus practical advice on how many places to visit.

Top Vietnamese cities for culinary experiences (what to eat there)
- Hanoi (North) — iconic street food: pho, bun cha, bun thang, egg coffee, cha ca; strong focus on subtle, balanced flavors and snacks from long-standing street vendors.
- Ho Chi Minh City / Saigon (South) — bold, sweet-savory southern flavors: banh mi, com tam, hu tieu, fresh seafood, vibrant night markets and huge street-food variety.
- Hoi An (Central coast) — regional specialties like cao lau, white rose dumplings, banh mi Phuong; great for food tours and cooking classes in a compact town.
- Hue (Central) — imperial/royal cuisine and spicy central dishes: bun bo Hue, banh khoai, complex small-plate traditions.
- Can Tho / Mekong Delta — floating markets, river-fresh produce and fish, tropical fruit, truly regional dishes and home-cooked experiences.
- Da Nang and coastal towns — fresh seafood, modern cafés and beachside dining; good as a stop between Hoi An and Hue.

Focus on a few places or travel around?
- If you have limited time (4–7 days): focus on 1–2 cities to get depth — e.g., Hanoi + Halong/ Ninh Binh day trips, or HCMC + Mekong Delta or Hoi An/Da Nang region. This yields a richer food experience and less travel stress.
- If you have ~10–14 days: 3–4 cities work well (Hanoi → Hue/ Hoi An → Da Nang → Ho Chi Minh City) to sample northern, central, and southern cuisines.
- If you have 3+ weeks or love moving often: you can travel around more widely and taste many micro-regional specialties, but plan travel days so you’re not eating on buses constantly.
- Practical tip: Vietnam is long north-to-south — flying between distant cities saves time and maximizes food time. Trains/buses are good for shorter hops or scenic routes.

If you want sample itineraries:
- Short (5 days): Hanoi 3 days (street food tour + markets + day trip), fly to Hoi An 2 days (food tour + cooking class).
- Medium (10 days): Hanoi → Hue → Hoi An/Da Nang → fly to HCMC → Mekong Delta day trip.
- Long (14+ days): add northern mountain cuisines (Sapa), more Mekong towns, and island/coastal seafood stops.

Would you like me to plan an itinerary or food-focused route? To help with a tailored plan, I just need a few details:
- Destination (I assume Vietnam — confirm?)
- Start date and end date (or approximate travel window)
- Budget range (total or per person; low/medium/high or $–$)
- Travel style (luxury, mid-range, budget, adventure, relaxed, foodie-focused, etc.)
- Number of people traveling
Optional but helpful: trip length in days, any dietary restrictions or must-try dishes, and how much moving between cities you want.

Tell me those details and I’ll save them and pass you to our destination research agent to build a food-focused plan.

- Hanoi (North) — iconic street food: pho, bun cha, bun thang, egg coffee, cha ca; strong focus on subtle, balanced flavors and snacks from long-standing street vendors.
- Ho Chi Minh City / Saigon (South) — bold, sweet-savory southern flavors: banh mi, com tam, hu tieu, fresh seafood, vibrant night markets and huge street-food variety.
- Hoi An (Central coast) — regional specialties like cao lau, white rose dumplings, banh mi Phuong; great for food tours and cooking classes in a compact town.
- Hue (Central) — imperial/royal cuisine and spicy central dishes: bun bo Hue, banh khoai, complex small-plate traditions.
- Can Tho / Mekong Delta — floating markets, river-fresh produce and fish, tropical fruit, truly regional dishes and home-cooked experiences.
- Da Nang and coastal towns — fresh seafood, modern cafés and beachside dining; good as a stop between Hoi An and Hue.

Focus on a few places or travel around?
- If you have limited time (4–7 days): focus on 1–2 cities to get depth — e.g., Hanoi + Halong/ Ninh Binh day trips, or HCMC + Mekong Delta or Hoi An/Da Nang region. This yields a richer food experience and less travel stress.
- If you have ~10–14 days: 3–4 cities work well (Hanoi → Hue/ Hoi An → Da Nang → Ho Chi Minh City) to sample northern, central, and southern cuisines.
- If you have 3+ weeks or love moving often: you can travel around more widely and taste many micro-regional specialties, but plan travel days so you’re not eating on buses constantly.
- Practical tip: Vietnam is long north-to-south — flying between distant cities saves time and maximizes food time. Trains/buses are good for shorter hops or scenic routes.

If you want sample itineraries:
- Short (5 days): Hanoi 3 days (street food tour + markets + day trip), fly to Hoi An 2 days (food tour + cooking class).
- Medium (10 days): Hanoi → Hue → Hoi An/Da Nang → fly to HCMC → Mekong Delta day trip.
- Long (14+ days): add northern mountain cuisines (Sapa), more Mekong towns, and island/coastal seafood stops.
